definitions.title: n.pr.deae.
definitions.body: ‘Aštōreth, < ‘Aštārt, ‘Aštêreth (v. infr.) (MI:17 [[עשתר כמש]]; Ph. [[עשתרת]] (+ oft. in n.pr.), n.pr. [[עבד עשתר]] Cook:Acad. Jan.18, 1896 Sab. n. pr. dei [[עתַתר]] v. esp. Os:ZMG xx (1866), 279 f. DHM:ib. xxxvii (1883), 376 Fell:Sab. Gotternamen, ZMG liv (1900), 231 ff., esp. 237 ff.; As Isûtar; OAram. Palm. [[עתר]] (= [[עתַתר]]) in n. pr.; in Egypt. ‘astirati WMM:As. u. Eur. 313; Gk. ‘ Asta/rth; on their Gk. equivalents (e.g. ï Afrodi/th) cf. Lewy:Fremdw. 148, 186 f, 250);—[[]]—[[ֶׁ]] prob. artificial, to suggest [[בּשֶׁת]], orig. [[תַּרְתְּ]]-, [[תֶּרֶת]]-, cf. Isûtar, Astarth, etc.; ´[[ע]] 1Ki 11:5 + 2 t.; pl. [[תָּרוֹת]]- Ju Jdg 2:13 + 3t.+ [[רׂת]]- 1Sa 7:4; 1Sa 31:10 rd. prob. sg. (Dr al.);—‘Aštart, ‘Aštereth (Astarth, pl. Astartai, but Ju Jdg 10:6, 1Sa 7:4 Astarwq), ancient Sem. goddess (with male counterpart in Moab., Sab. and appar. Ph.); Phoenician deity, [[עשׁתרת אֱלֽהֵי חִדׂנִים]] 1Ki 11:5, 1Ki 11:33, ´[[שִׁקֻּץ ח]] ´[[ע]] 2Ki 23:13; so prob. ´[[בֵּית ע]] 1Sa 31:10 (rdg. sg.; v. esp. Dr); elsewhere pl., of various local goddesses, called [[עֲשְׁתָּרוֹת]] (cf. As. ilâni u ištarat = gods and Ištars (i.e. goddesses), usu. + ([[ים]])[[בעל]], as Canaanitish deities Ju Jdg 2:13, Jdg 10:6, 1Sa 7:4, 1Sa 12:10; ‖[[אֱלֽהֵי הַנֵּכָר]] 1Sa 7:3.—Vid. esp. Dr:Ashtoreth in Hast:DB; on Iîitar Jastr:Rel. Bab. pass. esp. 202 f.; on ‘Athtar Bae:Rel. 117 f; on Ph. on ‘Aštart Pietschm:Gesch. Phön. 184 f.; on ‘Ashtoreth Barton:JBL x (1891), 73 ff. GFM:Ency. Bib.
